words.def: at, to, by, for, in, in the style of...
words.name: a or à (Fre)

words.def: see a due
words.name: a 2

words.def: Return to normal tempo after a deviation. Not recommended in string parts, due to possible confusion with battuto (qv.); use a tempo, which means the same thing.
words.name: a battuta

words.def: Up to the performer
words.name: a bene placito

words.def: (i.e. without instrumental accompaniment)
words.name: a cappella

words.def: A free and capricious approach to tempo
words.name: a capriccio

words.def: intended as a duet; for two voices or instruments; together; two instruments are to play in unison after a solo passage for one of the instruments
words.name: a due

words.def: To nothing; an indication to hold a fermata until it dies away (this only works with instruments which cannot sustain a note)
words.name: a nessuna cosa

words.def: To nothing; an indication to make a diminuendo which fades to pppp
words.name: a niente

words.def: At pleasure (i.e. the performer need not follow the rhythm strictly, for example in a cadenza)
words.name: a piacere

words.def: Sight-read (lit. "at first sight") (i.e. played or sung from written notation but without prior review of the written material)
words.name: a prima vista

words.def: In time (i.e. the performer should return to the main tempo of the piece, such as after an accelerando or ritardando); also may be found in combination with other terms such as a tempo giusto (in strict time) or a tempo di menuetto (at the speed of a minuet)
words.name: a tempo

words.def: off, organ stops or mutes
words.name: ab (Ger)

words.def: muffled, muted
words.name: abafando (Por)

words.def: free, unrestrained, passionate
words.name: abandon or avec (Fre)

words.def: free, relaxed
words.name: abbandonatamente, con abbandono

words.def: but
words.name: aber (Ger)

words.def: Expressive and caressing
words.name: accarezzévole

words.def: Accelerating; gradually increasing the tempo
words.name: accelerando (accel.)

words.def: suddenly increasing the tempo
words.name: accelerato

words.def: Emphasize, make a particular part more important
words.name: accent

words.def: Accented; with emphasis
words.name: accentato/accentuato

words.def: Ignited, on fire
words.name: acceso

words.def: Music that is easy to listen to/understand
words.name: accessible

words.def: Broken down, crushed; the sounding of the notes of a chord not quite simultaneously, but from bottom to top.
words.name: acciaccato

words.def: Crushing (i.e. a very fast grace note that is "crushed" against the note that follows and takes up no value in the measure)
words.name: acciaccatura

words.def: Accompanied (i.e. with the accompaniment following the soloist, who may speed up or slow down at will)
words.name: accompagnato

words.def: Precision; accuracy con accuratezza: with precision
words.name: accuratezza

words.def: Relating to music produced by instruments, as opposed to electric or electronic means
words.name: acoustic

words.def: At liberty (i.e. the speed and manner of execution are left to the performer)
words.name: ad libitum (commonly ad lib; Latin)

words.def: Rather slow (but faster than adagio)
words.name: adagietto

words.def: At ease (i.e. play slowly)
words.name: adagio

words.def: Very, very slow
words.name: adagissimo

words.def: Anguished
words.name: affannato, affannoso

words.def: with affect (that is, with emotion)
words.name: affetto or con affetto

words.def: With affect (that is, with emotion); see also con affetto
words.name: affettuoso, affettuosamente, or affectueusement (Fre)

words.def: Hurrying, pressing onwards
words.name: affrettando

words.def: Swiftly
words.name: agile

words.def: Agitated
words.name: agitato

words.def: To the, in the manner of (al before masculine nouns, alla before feminine)
words.name: al or alla

words.def: lit. "no restriction", used in con alcuna licenza to mean (play) with some freedom in the time, see rubato
words.name: alcuna licenza

words.def: "at the octave", see ottava
words.name: all' ottava

words.def: In cut-time; two beats per measure or the equivalent thereof
words.name: alla breve

words.def: In the style of a march
words.name: alla marcia

words.def: In the style of a Polonaise
words.name: alla polacca

words.def: Broadening, becoming a little slower each time
words.name: allargando

words.def: A little lively, moderately fast
words.name: allegretto

words.def: A moderately quick tempo
words.name: allegretto vivace

words.def: Cheerfulness, joyfulness
words.name: allegrezza

words.def: Very fast, though slower than presto
words.name: allegrissimo

words.def: Cheerful or brisk; but commonly interpreted as lively, fast
words.name: allegro

words.def: Than
words.name: als (Ger)

words.def: A jazz term which instructs chord-playing musicians such as a jazz pianist or jazz guitarist to perform a dominant (V7) chord with at least one (often both) altered (sharpened or flattened) 5th or 9th
words.name: alt (Eng), alt dom, or altered dominant

words.def: Very high
words.name: altissimo

words.def: High; often refers to a particular range of voice, higher than a tenor but lower than a soprano
words.name: alto

words.def: Lift or raise the mutes (i.e. remove mutes)
words.name: alzate sordini

words.def: At the bridge (i.e. playing a bowed string instrument near its bridge, which produces a heavier, stronger tone). See sul ponticello.
words.name: am Steg (Ger)

words.def: Amiable, pleasant
words.name: amabile

words.def: Range between highest and lowest note
words.name: ambitus

words.def: Love, con amore: with love, tenderly
words.name: amore or amor (in Spanish/Portuguese and sometimes in Italian)

words.def: Loving
words.name: amoroso

words.def: A note or notes that precede the first full bar; a pickup
words.name: anacrusis

words.def: Used to refer to a fugue subject of above-average length
words.name: andamento

words.def: At a walking pace (i.e. at a moderate tempo)
words.name: andante

words.def: Slightly faster than andante (but earlier it is sometimes used to mean slightly slower than andante)
words.name: andantino

words.def: Anxiously
words.name: ängstlich (Ger)

words.def: Life; feeling con anima : With feeling
words.name: anima

words.def: Animated, lively
words.name: animandosi

words.def: Animated, lively
words.name: animato

words.def: A liturgical or other composition consisting of choral responses, sometimes between two choirs; a passage of this nature forming part of another composition; a repeated passage in a psalm or other liturgical piece, similar to a refrain.[1]
words.name: antiphon

words.def: Calmed
words.name: apaisé (Fre)

words.def: Passionately
words.name: appassionato

words.def: One or more grace notes that take up some note value of the next full note.
words.name: appoggiatura or leaning note

words.def: The bow used for playing some string instrument (i.e. played with the bow, as opposed to pizzicato, in music for bowed instruments); normally used to cancel a pizzicato direction
words.name: arco

words.def: Self-contained piece for one voice usually with orchestral accompaniment
words.name: aria

words.def: A short aria
words.name: arietta

words.def: Airy, or like an air (a melody) (i.e. in the manner of an aria); melodious
words.name: arioso

words.def: Harmoniously
words.name: armonioso

words.def: like a harp (i.e. the notes of the chords are to be played quickly one after another instead of simultaneously). In music for piano, this is sometimes a solution in playing a wide-ranging chord whose notes cannot be played otherwise. Arpeggios are frequently used as an accompaniment. See also broken chord.
words.name: arpeggio

words.def: A way of playing a chord: starting with the lowest note, and with successively higher notes rapidly joining in. Sometimes the effect is reversed, so that the highest note is played first.
words.name: arpeggiato

words.def: Articulately
words.name: articulato

words.def: Much, Very much
words.name: assai

words.def: Enough, sufficiently
words.name: assez (Fre)

words.def: Attack or attach; go straight on (i.e. at the end of a movement, a direction to attach the next movement to the previous one, without a gap or pause)
words.name: attacca

words.def: Expression
words.name: Ausdruck (Ger)

words.def: Expressively, with expression
words.name: ausdrucksvoll or mit Ausdruck (Ger)

words.def: With or with another
words.name: avec (Fre)

words.def: German for B flat (also in Swedish, Norwegian, Finnish, Icelandic, Danish, Croatian, Estonian and Hungarian); H in German is B natural
words.name: B

words.def: (from the Italian Ballabile meaning "danceable") In ballet the term refers to a dance performed by the corps de ballet. The term Grand ballabile is used if nearly all participants (including principal characters) of a particular scene in a full-length work perform a large-scale dance.
words.name: ballabile

words.def: Barbarous (notably used in Allegro barbaro by Béla Bartók)
words.name: barbaro

words.def: A term that instructs string performers to play a pizzicato note to pull the string away from the fingerboard so that it snaps back percussively on the fingerboard.
words.name: Bartók pizzicato

words.def: The lowest of the standard four voice ranges (bass, tenor, alto, soprano); the lowest melodic line in a musical composition, often thought of as defining and supporting the harmony; in an orchestral context, the term usually refers to the double bass.
words.name: bass

words.def: Continuous bass (i.e. a bass part played continuously throughout a piece to give harmonic structure), used especially in the Baroque period
words.name: basso continuo

words.def: Used in the 17th-century to refer to ornaments consisting of two adjacent notes, such as trills or mordents
words.name: battement (Fre)

words.def: To strike the strings with the bow (on a bowed stringed instrument)
words.name: battuto (Ita)

words.def: 1. The pronounced rhythm of music
words.name: beat

words.def: Spirited, vivacious, lively
words.name: belebt or belebter (Ger)

words.def: Warlike, aggressive
words.name: bellicoso

words.def: Well; in ben marcato ("well marked") for example
words.name: ben or bene

words.def: Jazz term referring either to establishing a pitch, sliding down half a step and returning to the original pitch or sliding up half a step from the original note.
words.name: bend

words.def: Accelerated, as in mit beschleunigter Geschwindigkeit, at an accelerated tempo
words.name: beschleunigte (Ger)

words.def: Moved, with speed
words.name: bewegt (Ger)

words.def: A musical form in two sections: AB
words.name: binary

words.def: A slang term for fermata, which instructs the performer to hold a note or chord as long as they wish
words.name: bird's eye

words.def: Twice (i.e. repeat the relevant action or passage)
words.name: bis (Lat)

words.def: Whispering (i.e. a special tremolo effect on the harp where a chord or note is rapidly repeated at a low volume)
words.name: bisbigliando

words.def: with closed mouth
words.name: bocca chiusa

words.def: Boldness; as in con bravura, boldly
words.name: bravura

words.def: Broad
words.name: breit (Ger)

words.def: Transitional passage connecting two sections of a composition, also transition. Also the part of a stringed instrument that holds the strings in place and transmits their vibrations to the resonant body of the instrument.
words.name: bridge

words.def: Brilliantly, with sparkle
words.name: brillante

words.def: Vigour; usually in con brio: with spirit or vigour
words.name: brio or brioso

words.def: A chord in which the notes are not all played at once, but in some more or less consistent sequence. They may follow singly one after the other, or two notes may be immediately followed by another two, for example. See also arpeggio, which as an accompaniment pattern may be seen as a kind of broken chord; see Alberti bass.
words.name: broken chord

words.def: Brusquely
words.name: bruscamente

words.def: The concluding, rapid, audience-rousing section of an aria
words.name: cabaletta

words.def: A solo section, usually in a concerto or similar work, that is used to display the performer's technique, sometimes at considerable length
words.name: cadenza

words.def: Falling away, or lowering (i.e. getting slower and quieter; ritardando along with diminuendo)
words.name: calando

words.def: Calm; so con calma, calmly. Also calmato meaning calmed, relaxed
words.name: calma

words.def: Warmth; so con calore, warmly
words.name: calore

words.def: To change (i.e. any change, such as to a new instrument)
words.name: cambiare

words.def: A theme that is repeated and imitated and built upon by other instruments with a time delay, creating a layered effect; see Pachelbel's Canon.
words.name: canon or kanon (Ger)

words.def: In a singing style. In instrumental music, a style of playing that imitates the way the human voice might express the music, with a measured tempo and flexible, legato.
words.name: cantabile or cantando

words.def: Chorus; choral; chant
words.name: canto

words.def: 1. (short for capotasto: "nut") : A key-changing device for stringed instruments (e.g. guitars and banjos)
words.name: Capo

words.def: "A humorous, fanciful, or bizarre, composition, often characterized by an idiosyncratic departure from current stylistic norms."[2] See also: Capriccio (disambiguation)
words.name: capriccio

words.def: Capriciously, unpredictable, volatile
words.name: capriccioso

words.def: Chivalrously (used in Carl Nielsen's violin concerto)
words.name: cavalleresco

words.def: Yield, give way
words.name: cédez (Fre)

words.def: Break, stop; (i.e. a complete break in sound) (sometimes nicknamed "railroad tracks" in reference to their appearance)
words.name: cesura or caesura (Lat)

words.def: Closed (i.e. muted by hand) (for a horn, or similar instrument; but see also bocca chiusa, which uses the feminine form)
words.name: chiuso

words.def: A tail (i.e. a closing section appended to a movement)
words.name: coda

words.def: A small coda, but usually applied to a passage appended to a section of a movement, not to a whole movement
words.name: codetta

words.def: with the (col before a masculine noun, colla before a feminine noun); (see next for example)
words.name: col or colla

words.def: With the wood (i.e. the strings) (for example, of a violin) are to be struck with the wood of the bow, making a percussive sound; also battuta col legno: beaten with the wood
words.name: col legno

words.def: With the fist (i.e. bang the piano with the fist)
words.name: col pugno

words.def: With the addition of the octave note above or below the written note; abbreviated as col 8, coll' 8, and c. 8va
words.name: coll'ottava

words.def: With the soloist; as an instruction in an orchestral score or part, it instructs the conductor or orchestral musician to follow the rhythm and tempo of a solo performer (usually for a short passage)
words.name: colla parte

words.def: With the voice; as an instruction in a choral music/opera score or orchestral part, it instructs the conductor or orchestral musician to follow the rhythm and tempo of a solo singer (usually for a short passage)
words.name: colla voce

words.def: Coloration (i.e. elaborate ornamentation of a vocal line, or a soprano voice that is well-suited to such elaboration)
words.name: coloratura

words.def: Tremendously
words.name: colossale

words.def: Like the first (time) (i.e. as before, typically referring to an earlier tempo)
words.name: come prima

words.def: As above (i.e. like the previous tempo)
words.name: come sopra

words.def: The time signature 4/4: four beats per measure, each beat a quarter note (a crotchet) in length. 4/4 is often written on the musical staff as . The symbol is not a C as an abbreviation for common time, but a broken circle; the full circle at one time stood for triple time, 3/4.
words.name: common time

words.def: Comfortable (i.e. at moderate speed); also, allegro comodo, tempo comodo, etc.
words.name: comodo

words.def: With; used in very many musical directions, for example con allegrezza (with liveliness), con amore (with tenderness); (see also col and colla)
words.name: con

words.def: With a mute, or with mutes, See Sordina. Frequently seen in music as (incorrect Italian) con sordino, or con sordini (plural).
words.name: con sordina or con sordine (plural)

words.def: An adjective applied to a melodic line that moves by step (intervals of a 2nd) rather in disjunct motion (by leap).
words.name: conjunct

words.def: Lowest female singing voice type
words.name: contralto

words.def: See counterpoint
words.name: contrapuntalism

words.def: (plural of coperto) covered (i.e. on a drum, muted with a cloth)
words.name: coperti

words.def: String. On piano refers to use of the soft pedal which controls whether the hammer strikes one or three strings; see una corda, tre corde below.
words.name: corda

words.def: Growing; (i.e. progressively louder) (contrast diminuendo)
words.name: crescendo

words.def: Brassy. Used almost exclusively as a French Horn technique to indicate a forced, rough tone. A note marked both stopped and loud will be cuivré automatically[1]
words.name: cuivré

words.def: Symbol at the very end of a staff of music which indicates the pitch for the first note of the next line as a warning of what is to come. The custos was commonly used in handwritten Renaissance and typeset Baroque music.
words.name: custos

words.def: Same as the meter 2/2: two half-note (minim) beats per measure. Notated and executed like common time (4/4), except with the beat lengths doubled. Indicated by . This comes from a literal cut of the  symbol of common time. Thus, a quarter note in cut time is only half a beat long, and a measure has only two beats. See also alla breve.
words.name: cut time

words.def: From the head (i.e. from the beginning) (see capo)
words.name: da capo

words.def: From the sign ()
words.name: Dal Segno (D.S.)

words.def: Repeat back to the sign
words.name: dal segno al coda (D.S. al coda)

words.def: From the sign to the end (i.e. return to a place in the music designated by the sign  and continue to the end of the piece)
words.name: dal segno al fine (D.S. al fine)

words.def: Same as D.S. al coda, but with a double segno
words.name: dal segno segno al coda (D.S.S. al coda)

words.def: From the double sign to the end (i.e. return to place in the music designated by the double sign (see D.S. al coda) and continue to the end of the piece)
words.name: dal segno segno al fine (D.S.S. al fine)

words.def: Slowing down; decelerating; opposite of accelerando (same as ritardando or rallentando)
words.name: decelerando

words.def: Decisively
words.name: deciso

words.def: Solemn, expressive, impassioned
words.name: declamando

words.def: Same as diminuendo
words.name: decrescendo (decresc.)

words.def: From the Latin deesse meaning to be missing; placed after a catalogue abbreviation to indicate that this particular work does not appear in it.[3] The plural, desunt, is used when referring to several works.
words.name: deest

words.def: Delicately
words.name: delicatamente or delicato

words.def: Act of playing notes separately
words.name: détaché (Fre)

words.def: Religiously
words.name: devoto

words.def: Dwindling (i.e. with gradually decreasing volume) (same as decrescendo)
words.name: diminuendo, dim.

words.def: An adjective applied to a melodic line which moves by leap (intervals of more than a 2nd) as opposed to conjunct motion (by step)
words.name: disjunct

words.def: Of
words.name: di

words.def: Dissonant
words.name: dissonante

words.def: Divided (i.e. in a part in which several musicians normally play exactly the same notes they are instead to split the playing of the written simultaneous notes among themselves). It is most often used for string instruments, since with them another means of execution is often possible. (The return from divisi is marked unisono: see unison.)
words.name: divisi (div.)

words.def: Jazz term referring to a note that slides to an indefinite pitch chromatically upwards.
words.name: doit

words.def: Sweetly
words.name: dolce

words.def: Very sweetly
words.name: dolcissimo

words.def: Sorrowfully, plaintively
words.name: dolente

words.def: Pain, distress, sorrow, grief con dolore: with sadness
words.name: dolore

words.def: Sorrowfully, plaintively
words.name: doloroso

words.def: Twice as fast
words.name: doppio movimento

words.def: Two dots placed side by side after a note to indicate that it is to be lengthened by three quarters of its value.
words.name: double dot

words.def: The technique of playing two notes simultaneously on a bowed string instrument
words.name: double stop

words.def: A slow, moody, or decreased tempo or played or done in such a tempo. It also refers to a genre of electronic music based on this (downtempo).
words.name: downtempo

words.def: Dramatically
words.name: drammatico

words.def: Bass note or chord performed continuously throughout a composition
words.name: drone

words.def: Jazz term referring to a note that slides to an indefinite pitch chromatically downwards
words.name: drop

words.def: (Ita) grief
words.name: duolo

words.def: Dull
words.name: dumpf (Ger)

words.def: major; used in key signatures as, for example, A-Dur (A major), B-Dur (B♭ major), or H-Dur (B major). (see also Moll (minor).)
words.name: Dur (Ger)

words.def: The relative volume in the execution of a piece of music
words.name: dynamics

words.def: And
words.name: e (Ita) or ed (Ita, – used before vowels)

words.def: The Italian word for "echo"; an effect in which a group of notes is repeated, usually more softly, and perhaps at a different octave, to create an echo effect
words.name: eco

words.def: A little
words.name: ein wenig (Ger)

words.def: Feeling
words.name: Empfindung (Ger)

words.def: Prominently
words.name: en dehors (Fre)

words.def: Hurrying forward
words.name: en pressant (Fre)

words.def: Slowing
words.name: en retenant (Fre)

words.def: Again (i.e. perform the relevant passage once more)
words.name: encore (Fre)

words.def: Energetic, strong
words.name: energico

words.def: Emphatically
words.name: enfatico

words.def: Heroically
words.name: eroico

words.def: Effusive; excessive in emotional expression; gushy.
words.name: espansivo

words.def: Expiring (i.e. dying away)
words.name: espirando

words.def: Expression; expressively (e.g. con (gran, molta) espressione: with (great, much) expression)
words.name: espressione

words.def: Expressively
words.name: espressivo or espr.

words.def: Extinct, extinguished (i.e. as soft as possible, lifeless, barely audible)
words.name: estinto

words.def: Somewhat
words.name: etwas (Ger)

words.def: Easily, without fuss
words.name: facile

words.def: Jazz term describing a note of definite pitch sliding downwards to another note of definite pitch.
words.name: fall

words.def: vocal register above the normal voice
words.name: falsetto

words.def: A piece not adhering to any strict musical form. Can also be used in con fantasia: with imagination
words.name: fantasia

words.def: Solemn, solemnly
words.name: feierlich (Ger)

words.def: Finished, closed (i.e. a rest or note is to be held for a duration that is at the discretion of the performer or conductor) (sometimes called bird's eye); a fermata at the end of a first or intermediate movement or section is usually moderately prolonged, but the final fermata of a symphony may be prolonged for longer than the note's value, typically twice its printed length or more for dramatic effect.
words.name: fermata

words.def: Ferociously
words.name: feroce

words.def: Cheerfully, celebratory
words.name: festivamente

words.def: Fiery
words.name: feurig (Ger)

words.def: Proudly
words.name: fieramente

words.def: "thread of voice", very quiet, pianissimo
words.name: fil di voce

words.def: A jazz or rock term which instructs performers to improvise a scalar passage or riff to "fill in" the brief time between lyrical phrases, the lines of melody, or between two sections
words.name: fill (Eng)

words.def: The end, often in phrases like al fine (to the end)
words.name: fine

words.def: A symbol (♭) that lowers the pitch of a note by a semitone. The term may also be used as an adjective to describe a situation where a singer or musician is performing a note in which the intonation is an eighth or a quarter of a semitone too low.
words.name: flat

words.def: Flutelike; used especially for string instruments to indicate a light, rapid bowing over the fingerboard
words.name: flautando or flautendo

words.def: Mournfully
words.name: flebile

words.def: Fiery (i.e. passionately)
words.name: focoso or fuocoso

words.def: Strong (i.e. to be played or sung loudly)
words.name: forte (f)

words.def: Strong-gentle (i.e. loud, then immediately soft (see dynamics), or an early pianoforte)
words.name: forte piano (fp)

words.def: Very loud (see note at pianissimo)
words.name: fortissimo (ff)

words.def: As loud as possible
words.name: fortississimo (fff)

words.def: Musical force con forza: with force
words.name: forza

words.def: See sforzando
words.name: forzando (fz)

words.def: Cold(ly); hence depressive, unemotional
words.name: freddo

words.def: Freshly
words.name: fresco

words.def: Lively, joyfully
words.name: fröhlich (Ger)

words.def: Literally "flight"; hence a complex and highly regimented contrapuntal form in music. A short theme (the subject) is introduced in one voice (or part) alone, then in others, with imitation and characteristic development as the piece progresses.
words.name: fugue (Fre), fuga (Latin and Italian)

words.def: Funeral; often seen as marcia funebre (funeral march), indicating a stately and plodding tempo.
words.name: funebre

words.def: Fire; con fuoco: with fire, in a fiery manner
words.name: fuoco

words.def: Fury
words.name: furia

words.def: Furiously
words.name: furioso

words.def: Grand Pause, General Pause; indicates to the performers that the entire ensemble has a rest of indeterminate length, often as a dramatic effect during a loud section
words.name: G.P.

words.def: With joy
words.name: gaudioso

words.def: Unhurried, at a leisurely pace
words.name: gemächlich (Ger)

words.def: Groaningly
words.name: gemendo

words.def: Gently
words.name: gentile

words.def: Quickly
words.name: geschwind (Ger)

words.def: See divisi
words.name: geteilt (Ger)

words.def: Solemnly, in a stately tempo
words.name: getragen (Ger)

words.def: Gaily
words.name: giocoso or gioioso

words.def: Strictly, exactly (e.g. tempo giusto in strict time)
words.name: giusto

words.def: A continuous sliding from one pitch to another (a true glissando), or an incidental scale executed while moving from one melodic note to another (an effective glissando). See glissando for further information; and compare portamento.
words.name: glissando

words.def: An extra note added as an embellishment and not essential to the harmony or melody.
words.name: grace note

words.def: Grandly
words.name: grandioso

words.def: Slowly and seriously
words.name: grave

words.def: Gracefully
words.name: grazioso

words.def: War-like
words.name: guerriero

words.def: With happy emphasis and forcefulness
words.name: gustoso

words.def: German for B natural; B in German means B flat
words.name: H

words.def: Main voice, chief part (i.e. the contrapuntal line of primary importance, in opposition to Nebenstimme)
words.name: Hauptstimme (Ger)

words.def: The imposition of a pattern of rhythm or articulation other than that implied by the time signature; specifically, in triple time (for example in 3/4) the imposition of a duple pattern (as if the time signature were, for example, 2/4). See Syncopation.
words.name: hemiola (English, from Greek)

words.def: Prominent, pronounced
words.name: hervortretend (Ger)

words.def: A musical texture with one voice (or melody line) accompanied by chords; also used as an adjective (homophonic). Compare with polyphony, in which several voices or melody lines are performed at the same time.
words.name: Homophony

words.def: Always
words.name: immer (Ger)

words.def: Imperiously
words.name: imperioso

words.def: Impetuously
words.name: impetuoso

words.def: With improvisation
words.name: improvvisando

words.def: Improvised, or as if improvised
words.name: improvvisato

words.def: octave above the treble staff, G5 to F6[4]
words.name: in alt

words.def: Octave above the in alt octave, G6 to F7
words.name: in altissimo

words.def: In the art of, in the style of
words.name: in modo di

words.def: A term for brass players that requires them to direct the bell of their instrument into the music stand, instead of up and toward the audience, thus muting the sound but without changing the timbre as a mute would[5]
words.name: in stand

words.def: Getting faster and louder
words.name: incalzando

words.def: Intimately, heartfelt
words.name: innig

words.def: Insistently, deliberate
words.name: insistendo

words.def: Intimately
words.name: intimo

words.def: Opening section
words.name: intro

words.def: Angrily
words.name: irato

words.def: A suffix meaning as ... as can be (e.g. leggerissimamente, meaning as light as can be)
words.name: -issimamente

words.def: A suffix meaning extremely (e.g. fortissimo or prestissimo)
words.name: -issimo

words.def: A well-known composition from the jazz repertoire which is widely played and recorded.
words.name: Jazz standard (or simply "standard")

words.def: jeté) : Jump; a bowing technique in which the player is instructed to let the bow bounce or jump off the strings.
words.name: jete (French

words.def: A musician who plays any instrument with a keyboard. In Classical music, this may refer to instruments such as the piano, pipe organ, harpsichord, and so on. In a jazz or popular music context, this may refer to instruments such as the piano, electric piano, synthesizer, Hammond organ, and so on.
words.name: keyboardist (Eng)

words.def: "tone-color-melody", distribution of pitch or melody among instruments, varying timbre
words.name: Klangfarbenmelodie (Ger)

words.def: Strongly
words.name: kräftig (Ger)

words.def: Tearfully (i.e. sadly)
words.name: lacrimoso or lagrimoso

words.def: French for lasciare suonare ("let vibrate").
words.name: laissez vibrer, l.v. (Fre)

words.def: Lamenting, mournfully
words.name: lamentando

words.def: Lamenting, mournfully
words.name: lamentoso

words.def: Slowly
words.name: langsam (Ger)

words.def: Broadly (i.e. slowly) (same as largo)
words.name: largamente

words.def: Somewhat slowly; not as slow as largo
words.name: larghetto

words.def: Broadness; con larghezza: with broadness; broadly
words.name: larghezza

words.def: Very slowly; slower than largo
words.name: larghissimo

words.def: Broadly (i.e. slowly)
words.name: largo

words.def: "Let ring", meaning allow the sound to continue, do not damp; used frequently in harp or guitar music, occasionally in piano or percussion. Abbreviated "lasc. suon."
words.name: lasciare suonare

words.def: A melodic interval greater than a major 2nd, as opposed to a step. Melodies which move by a leap are called "disjunct". Octave leaps are not uncommon in florid vocal music.
words.name: leap or skip

words.def: Briskly, lively
words.name: lebhaft (Ger)

words.def: Joined (i.e. smoothly, in a connected manner) (see also articulation)
words.name: legato

words.def: Very lightly and delicately
words.name: leggierissimo

words.def: Lightly, delicately (The different forms of this word, including leggierezza, "lightness", are properly spelled in Italian as legger, without the i.)
words.name: leggiero, leggiermente or leggiadro

words.def: Passionately
words.name: leidenschaftlich(er) (Ger)

words.def: Slowly
words.name: lent (Fre)

words.def: Gradual slowing and softer
words.name: lentando

words.def: Very slowly
words.name: lentissimo

words.def: Slowly
words.name: lento

words.def: Freely
words.name: liberamente

words.def: Free, freely
words.name: libero

words.def: A jaunty rhythm
words.name: lilt

words.def: The same tempo, despite changes of time signature, see metric modulation[6]
words.name: l'istesso, l'istesso tempo, or lo stesso tempo

words.def: The same; applied to the manner of articulation, tempo, etc.
words.name: lo stesso

words.def: [in] place (i.e. perform the notes at the pitch written, generally used to cancel an 8va or 8vb direction). In string music, also used to indicate return to normal playing position (see Playing the violin).[1]
words.name: loco

words.def: Hit hard and keep full value of note (>)
words.name: long accent

words.def: From a distance; distantly
words.name: lontano

words.def: Lugubrious, mournful
words.name: lugubre

words.def: Luminously
words.name: luminoso

words.def: Long (often applied to a fermata)
words.name: lunga

words.def: Coaxingly, flatteringly, caressingly
words.name: lusingando, lusinghiero

words.def: But
words.name: ma

words.def: But not too much
words.name: ma non troppo, ma non tanto

words.def: Majestically, in a stately fashion
words.name: maestoso

words.def: The major key
words.name: maggiore

words.def: Magically
words.name: magico

words.def: Magnificent
words.name: magnifico

words.def: [played with the] right hand (abbreviation: MD or m.d.)
words.name: main droite (Fre)

words.def: [played with the] left hand (abbreviation: MG or m.g.)
words.name: main gauche (Fre)

words.def: Melancholic
words.name: malinconico

words.def: Dying away
words.name: mancando

words.def: [played with the] right hand (abbreviation: MD or m.d.)
words.name: mano destra

words.def: [played with the] left hand (abbreviation: MS or m.s.)
words.name: mano sinistra

words.def: With much accentuation
words.name: marcatissimo

words.def: Marked (i.e. with accentuation, execute every note as if it were to be accented)
words.name: marcato, marc.

words.def: A march; alla marcia means in the manner of a march
words.name: marcia

words.def: Hammered out
words.name: martellato

words.def: Martial, solemn and fierce
words.name: marziale

words.def: (sometimes given as "mässig", "maessig") Moderately
words.name: mäßig (Ger)

words.def: See mano destra or main droite
words.name: MD

words.def: Also "bar" the period of a musical piece that encompasses a complete cycle of the time signature (e.g. in 4/4 time, a measure has four quarter note beats)
words.name: measure (Eng)

words.def: Same tempo, despite changes of time signature
words.name: medesimo tempo

words.def: Piece composed from parts of existing pieces, usually three, played one after another, sometimes overlapping.
words.name: medley

words.def: Melancholic
words.name: melancolico

words.def: The technique of changing the note (pitch) of a syllable of text while it is being sung
words.name: melisma

words.def: Less; see meno mosso, for example, less mosso
words.name: meno

words.def: In singing, a controlled swell (i.e. crescendo then diminuendo, on a long held note, especially in Baroque music and in the bel canto period)[1]
words.name: messa di voce

words.def: Mournful, sad
words.name: mesto

words.def: The pattern of a music piece's rhythm of strong and weak beats
words.name: meter or metre

words.def: Half voice (i.e. with subdued or moderated volume)
words.name: mezza voce

words.def: Half; used in combinations like mezzo forte (mf), meaning moderately loud
words.name: mezzo

words.def: Half loudly (i.e. moderately loudly). See dynamics.
words.name: mezzo forte

words.def: Half softly (i.e. moderately softly). See dynamics.
words.name: mezzo piano

words.def: A female singer with a range usually extending from the A below middle C to the F an eleventh above middle C. Mezzo-sopranos generally have a darker vocal tone than sopranos, and their vocal range is between that of a soprano and that of a contralto.
words.name: mezzo-soprano

words.def: See main gauche
words.name: MG

words.def: Mysteriously
words.name: misterioso

words.def: With a mute
words.name: mit Dämpfer (Ger)

words.def: Metronome Marking. Formerly "Mälzel Metronome." [7]
words.name: M.M.

words.def: Flexible, changeable
words.name: mobile

words.def: Moderate; often combined with other terms, usually relating to tempo; for example, allegro moderato
words.name: moderato

words.def: Moderately
words.name: modere (Fre)

words.def: Modest
words.name: modesto

words.def: The act or process of changing from one key (tonic, or tonal center) to another. This may or may not be accompanied by a change in key signature.
words.name: modulation

words.def: minor; used in key signatures as, for example, a-Moll (A minor), b-Moll (B♭ minor), or h-Moll (B minor) (see also Dur (major))
words.name: Moll (Ger)

words.def: Very
words.name: molto

words.def: Rapid alternation of a note with the note immediately below or above it in the scale, sometimes further distinguished as lower mordent and upper mordent. The term "inverted mordent" usually refers to the upper mordent.
words.name: mordent

words.def: Dying (i.e. dying away in dynamics, and perhaps also in tempo)
words.name: morendo

words.def: Moved, moving; used with a preceding più or meno, for faster or slower respectively
words.name: mosso

words.def: Motion; usually seen as con moto, meaning with motion or quickly
words.name: moto

words.def: A section of a musical composition (such as a sonata or concerto)
words.name: movement

words.def: See mano sinistra
words.name: MS

words.def: Lively
words.name: munter (Ger)

words.def: A dance or tune of a drone-bass character, originally played by a musette
words.name: Musette (Fre)

words.def: Change: either a change of instrument (e.g. flute to piccolo, horn in F to horn in Bb); or a change of tuning (e.g. guitar muta 6 in D). Note: does not mean "mute", for which con sordina or con sordino is used.[1] Muta comes from the Italian verb mutare (to change into something).
words.name: muta [in...]

words.def: Literally "more and more" with an increasing feeling. Ex. "nach und nach belebter und leidenschaftlicher" (with increasing animation and passion)
words.name: nach und nach (Ger)

words.def: Narratingly
words.name: narrante

words.def: A symbol (♮) that cancels the effect of a sharp or a flat
words.name: natural

words.def: Natural (i.e. discontinue a special effect, such as col legno, sul tasto, sul ponticello, or playing in harmonics)
words.name: naturale (nat.)

words.def: No chord, written in the chord row of music notation to show there is no chord being played, and no implied harmony
words.name: N.C.

words.def: Secondary part (i.e. a secondary contrapuntal part, always occurring simultaneously with, and subsidiary to, the Hauptstimme)
words.name: Nebenstimme (Ger)

words.def: Not
words.name: nicht (Ger)

words.def: "nothing", barely audible, dying away
words.name: niente

words.def: In a noble fashion
words.name: nobile or nobilmente (It) or Noblement (Fre)

words.def: Nobility
words.name: noblezza

words.def: A piece written for the night
words.name: nocturne (Fre)

words.def: Unequal notes; a principally Baroque performance practice of applying long-short rhythms to pairs of notes written as equal; see also swung note
words.name: notes inégales (Fre)

words.def: See nocturne.
words.name: notturno

words.def: An opera consisting of "numbers" (e.g. arias, intermixed with recitative)
words.name: number opera

words.def: Required, indispensable
words.name: obbligato

words.def: Interval between one musical pitch and another with half or double its frequency. Twelve semitones equals an octave, so does the first and eighth (hence "oct"ave) note in a major or minor scale.
words.name: octave

words.def: Without a mute
words.name: ohne Dämpfer (Ger)

words.def: Homage, celebration
words.name: omaggio

words.def: The practice of using solo voices on each musical line or part in choral music.
words.name: one-voice-per-part (OVPP)

words.def: In bowed string music, an indication to discontinue extended techniques such as sul ponticello, sul tasto or col legno, and return to normal playing. The same as "naturale".
words.name: ordinario (ord.) (Ita)

words.def: In jazz or rock, a group of three musicians which includes a Hammond organ player and two other instruments, often an electric guitar player and a drummer.
words.name: organ trio

words.def: Or instead (i.e. according to some specified alternative way of performing a passage, which is marked with a footnote, additional small notes, or an additional staff)
words.name: ossia or oppure

words.def: Obstinate, persistent (i.e. a short musical pattern that is repeated throughout an entire composition or portion of a composition)
words.name: ostinato

words.def: Octave (e.g. ottava bassa: an octave lower)
words.name: ottava

words.def: Like speech, enunciated
words.name: parlando or parlante

words.def: Full orchestral score
words.name: Partitur (Ger)

words.def: Passionately
words.name: passionato

words.def: In a pastoral style, peaceful and simple
words.name: pastorale

words.def: Passionately, with great emotion. A related term is Pathetique: A name attributed to certain works with an emotional focus such as Tchaikovsky's 6th symphony.
words.name: patetico

words.def: rest
words.name: pausa

words.def: In piano scores, this instructs the player to press the damper pedal to sustain the note or chord being played. The player may be instructed to release the pedal with an asterisk marking (*). In organ scores, it tells the organist that a section is to be performed on the bass pedalboard with the feet.
words.name: pedale or ped

words.def: Thoughtfully, meditatively
words.name: penseroso

words.def: Dying away; decrease in dynamics, perhaps also in tempo
words.name: perdendosi

words.def: Heavy, ponderous
words.name: pesante

words.def: Little by little
words.name: peu à peu (Fre)

words.def: A composition
words.name: pezzo

words.def: Pleasant, agreeable
words.name: piacevole

words.def: Literally 'crying' (used in Liszt's La Lugubre Gondola no. 2).
words.name: piangendo

words.def: Plaintive:
words.name: piangevole

words.def: very gently (i.e. perform very softly, even softer than piano). This convention can be extended; the more ps that are written, the softer the composer wants the musician to play or sing, thus ppp (pianississimo) would be softer than pp. Dynamics in a piece should be interpreted relative to the other dynamics in the same piece. For example, pp should be executed as softly as possible, but if ppp is found later in the piece, pp should be markedly louder than ppp. More than three ps (ppp) or three fs (fff) are uncommon.
words.name: pianissimo (pp)

words.def: Gently (i.e. played or sung softly) (see dynamics)
words.name: piano (p)

words.def: The same as a vocal score, a piano arrangement along with the vocal parts of an opera, cantata, or similar
words.name: piano-vocal score

words.def: A Picardy third, Picardy cadence (ˈpɪkərdi ) or, in French, tierce picarde is a harmonic device used in Western classical music.It refers to the use of a major chord of the tonic at the end of a musical section that is either modal or in a minor key.
words.name: Picardy third

words.def: Full, as, for example, a voce pienna = "in full voice"
words.name: pienna (Ita)

words.def: Pitiful, piteous
words.name: pietoso

words.def: More; see mosso
words.name: più

words.def: Rather, somewhat (e.g. allegro piuttosto presto)
words.name: piuttosto

words.def: Pinched, plucked (i.e. in music for bowed strings, plucked with the fingers as opposed to played with the bow; compare arco, which is inserted to cancel a pizzicato instruction; in music for guitar, to mute the strings by resting the palm on the bridge, simlulating the sound of pizz. of the bowed string instruments)
words.name: pizzicato

words.def: Jazz term referring to a note that slides to an indefinite pitch chromatically downwards.
words.name: plop

words.def: Very little; diminutive of poco
words.name: pochettino or poch.

words.def: Very little; superlative of poco
words.name: pochissimo or pochiss.

words.def: A little, as in poco più allegro (a little faster)
words.name: poco

words.def: Little by little
words.name: poco a poco

words.def: Poetic discourse
words.name: poetico

words.def: Then, indicating a subsequent instruction in a sequence; diminuendo poi subito fortissimo, for example: getting softer then suddenly very loud
words.name: poi

words.def: Pompous, ceremonious
words.name: pomposo

words.def: On the bridge (i.e. in string playing, an indication to bow or to pluck very near to the bridge, producing a characteristic glassy sound, which emphasizes the higher harmonics at the expense of the fundamental); the opposite of sul tasto
words.name: ponticello (pont.)

words.def: Carrying (i.e. 1. generally, sliding in pitch from one note to another, usually pausing just above or below the final pitch, then sliding quickly to that pitch. If no pause is executed, then it is a basic glissando; or 2. in piano music, an articulation between legato and staccato, like portato)
words.name: portamento

words.def: Carried (i.e. non-legato, but not as detached as staccato) (same as portamento)
words.name: portato or louré

words.def: Settled
words.name: posato

words.def: Potpourri (as used in other senses in English) (i.e. a kind of musical form structured as ABCDEF... etc.; the same as medley or, sometimes, fantasia)
words.name: potpourri or pot-pourri (Fre)

words.def: Precipitately
words.name: precipitato

words.def: A musical introduction to subsequent movements during the Baroque era (1600's/17th century). It can also be a movement in its own right, which was more common in the Romantic era (mid-1700s/18th century)
words.name: prelude, prélude (Fre), preludio (It), praeludium (Lat), präludium (Ger)

words.def: Extremely quickly, as fast as possible
words.name: prestissimo

words.def: Very quickly
words.name: presto

words.def: First
words.name: prima or primo (the masculine form)

words.def: Leading female singer in an opera company
words.name: prima donna

words.def: The first time; for example prima volta senza accompagnamento (the first time without accompaniment)
words.name: prima volta

words.def: Composed of the musical interval of the fourth; as in quartal harmony
words.name: quartal

words.def: Half of a semitone; a pitch division not used in most Western music notation, except in some contemporary art music or experimental music. Quarter tones are used in Western popular music forms such as jazz and blues and in a variety of non-Western musical cultures.
words.name: quarter tone

words.def: As if, almost (e.g. quasi recitativo like a recitative in an opera, or quasi una fantasia like a fantasia)
words.name: quasi (Latin and Italian)

words.def: Composed of the musical interval of the fifth; as in quintal harmony
words.name: quintal

words.def: Broadening of the tempo (often not discernible from ritardando); progressively slower
words.name: rallentando or rall.

words.def: Fast
words.name: rapide (Fre)

words.def: Fast
words.name: rapido

words.def: Fast
words.name: rasch (Ger)

words.def: (on the guitar) to play strings with the back of the fingernail; esp. to fan the strings rapidly with the nails of multiple fingers
words.name: rasguedo (Spa)

words.def: Quicken pace (as "ravvivando il tempo", returning to a faster tempo that occurred earlier in the piece)[8]
words.name: ravvivando (Ita, "reviving")

words.def: Recitatively; one voice without accompaniment
words.name: recitativo

words.def: Religiously
words.name: religioso

words.def: Suddenly
words.name: repente

words.def: Repeat a phrase or verse; return to the original theme
words.name: reprise

words.def: Stay (i.e. remain on a note or string)
words.name: restez (Fre)

words.def: Hold back; same as the Italian ritenuto (see below)
words.name: retenu (Fre)

words.def: Humorously, inaccurate, and loosely
words.name: ridicolosamente or ridicolo

words.def: Relaxed
words.name: rilassato

words.def: Reinforced (i.e. emphasized); sometimes like a sudden crescendo, but often applied to a single note
words.name: rinforzando (rf or rinf.)

words.def: Resolutely
words.name: risoluto

words.def: An abbreviation for ritardando;[9] also an abbreviation for ritenuto[10]
words.name: rit.

words.def: Slowing down; decelerating; opposite of accelerando
words.name: ritardando, ritard., rit.

words.def: Suddenly slower, held back (usually more so but more temporarily than a ritardando, and it may, unlike ritardando, apply to a single note); opposite of accelerato
words.name: ritenuto, riten., rit.

words.def: Rhythmical
words.name: ritmico

words.def: Rhythm (e.g. ritmo di # battute meaning a rhythm of # measures)
words.name: ritmo

words.def: A recurring passage for orchestra in the first or final movement of a solo concerto or aria (also in works for chorus).
words.name: ritornello

words.def: See arpeggiato
words.name: rolled chord

words.def: A musical form in which a certain section returns repeatedly, interspersed with other sections: ABACA is a typical structure or ABACABA
words.name: rondo

words.def: A rolling (i.e. a florid vocal phrase)
words.name: roulade (Fre)

words.def: Robbed (i.e. flexible in tempo), applied to notes within a musical phrase for expressive effect
words.name: rubato

words.def: Calm, peaceful
words.name: ruhig (Ger)

words.def: A rapid series of ascending or descending musical notes which are closely spaced in pitch forming a scale
words.name: run

words.def: Roughly
words.name: ruvido

words.def: Bouncing the bow as in a staccato arpeggio, literally means "jumping"
words.name: saltando

words.def: Gently
words.name: sanft (Ger)

words.def: Unchained, wildly[11]
words.name: scatenato

words.def: Playfully
words.name: scherzando, scherzoso

words.def: A light, "joking" or playful musical form, originally and usually in fast triple metre, often replacing the minuet in the later Classical period and the Romantic period, in symphonies, sonatas, string quartets and the like; in the 19th century some scherzi were independent movements for piano, etc.
words.name: scherzo

words.def: To drag; usually nicht schleppen ("don't drag"), paired with nicht eilen ("don't hurry") in Gustav Mahler's scores
words.name: schleppen (Ger)

words.def: Fast
words.name: schnell (Ger)

words.def: Faster
words.name: schneller (Ger)

words.def: Heavy
words.name: schwer (Ger)

words.def: Lively, swinging, bold, spirited
words.name: schwungvoll (Ger)

words.def: Fluency, agility (used in con scioltezza)
words.name: scioltezza

words.def: Out of tune (i.e. an alternative tuning used for the strings of a string instrument)
words.name: scordatura

words.def: Gliding from note to note
words.name: scorrendo, scorrevole

words.def: Dry (sparse accompaniment, staccato, without resonance)
words.name: secco (sec) (Fre)

words.def: sign, usually Dal Segno (see above) "from the sign", indicating a return to the point marked by
words.name: segno

words.def: Carry on to the next section without a pause
words.name: segue

words.def: Very
words.name: sehr (Ger)

words.def: The smallest pitch difference between notes (in most Western music) (e.g. F–F♯)
words.name: semitone

words.def: Simply
words.name: semplice

words.def: Always
words.name: sempre

words.def: Feeling, emotion
words.name: sentimento

words.def: Expressively
words.name: sentito

words.def: Without
words.name: senza

words.def: Without measure
words.name: senza misura

words.def: Without the mute. See sordina.
words.name: senza sordina or senza sordine (plural)

words.def: Seriously
words.name: serioso

words.def: Made loud (i.e. a sudden strong accent)
words.name: sforzando (sfz)

words.def: A jazz term describing a trill between one note and its minor third; or, with brass instruments, between a note and its next overblown harmonic.
words.name: shake

words.def: A symbol (♯) that raises the pitch of the note by a semitone. The term may also be used as an adjective to describe a situation where a singer or musician is performing a note in which the intonation is somewhat too high in pitch.
words.name: sharp

words.def: Hit the note hard and short (^)
words.name: short accent

words.def: Seventh note of the series ut, re, mi, fa, sol, la, si, in fixed-doh solmization.
words.name: si (Fre)

words.def: A Sicilian dance in 12/8 or 6/8 meter[12]
words.name: siciliana

words.def: See segno
words.name: sign

words.def: Silence (i.e. without reverberations)
words.name: silenzio

words.def: Similarly (i.e. continue applying the preceding directive, whatever it was, to the following passage)
words.name: simile

words.def: Curtain (stage)
words.name: sipario

words.def: Momentum, con slancio: with momentum; with enthusiasm
words.name: slancio

words.def: Becoming broader or slower (that is, becoming more largo or more lento)
words.name: slargando or slentando

words.def: Extinguishing or dampening; usually interpreted as a drop in dynamics, and very often in tempo as well
words.name: smorzando or smorz.

words.def: Smoothly, gently
words.name: soave

words.def: Dreamily
words.name: sognando

words.def: Solemn
words.name: solenne

words.def: Alone (i.e. executed by a single instrument or voice). The instruction soli requires more than one player or singer; in a jazz big band this refers to an entire section playing in harmony. In orchestral works, soli refers to a divided string section with only one player to a line.
words.name: solo or soli (plural)

words.def: A jazz term that instructs a lead player or rhythm section member to play an improvised solo cadenza for one or two measures (sometimes abbreviated as "break"), without any accompaniment. The solo part is often played in a rhythmically free manner, until the player performs a pickup or lead-in line, at which time the band recommences playing in the original tempo.
words.name: solo break

words.def: Sum; total, con somma passione: with great passion
words.name: somma (Ita)

words.def: A piece played as opposed to sung.
words.name: sonata

words.def: A little sonata
words.name: sonatina

words.def: A little sonata, used in some countries instead of sonatina
words.name: sonatine

words.def: Sonorous
words.name: sonore

words.def: Ringing
words.name: sonoro

words.def: Above
words.name: sopra

words.def: To be played on one string
words.name: sopra una corda or sull'istessa corda

words.def: The highest of the standard four voice ranges (bass, tenor, alto, soprano)
words.name: soprano

words.def: A mute, Note: sordina, with plural sordine, is strictly correct Italian, but the forms sordino and sordini are much more commonly used as terms in music. Instruments can have their tone muted with wood, rubber, metal, or plastic devices, (for string instruments, mutes are clipped to the bridge; for brass instruments, mutes are inserted in the bell), or parts of the body (guitar; French Horn), or fabric (clarinet; timpani), among other means. In piano music (notably in Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata), senza sordini or senza sordina (or some variant) is sometimes used to mean keep the sustain pedal depressed, since the sustain pedal lifts the dampers off the strings, with the effect that all notes are sustained indefinitely.
words.name: sordina, sordine (plural)

words.def: See sordina.
words.name: sordino

words.def: A principal singer's first entrance in an opera
words.name: sortita

words.def: Sighing
words.name: sospirando

words.def: Sustained, lengthened
words.name: sostenuto

words.def: In an undertone (i.e. quietly)
words.name: sotto voce

words.def: Smooth, even
words.name: spianato

words.def: Distinct, separated (i.e. a way of playing the violin and other bowed instruments by bouncing the bow on the string, giving a characteristic staccato effect)
words.name: spiccato

words.def: Literally "pushed"
words.name: spinto

words.def: Spirit, con spirito: with spirit; with feeling
words.name: spirito

words.def: Spiritedly
words.name: spiritoso

words.def: Making each note brief and detached; the opposite of legato. In musical notation, a small dot under or over the head of the note indicates that it is to be articulated as staccato.
words.name: staccato

words.def: A verse of a song
words.name: stanza

words.def: Labored, heavy, in a dragging manner, holding back each note
words.name: stentando

words.def: Originally truly 'improvised' now taken as 'appearing to be improvised,' an Italian 'folk' song, the style of which used for example by Puccini in certain of his operas.
words.name: stornello

words.def: Indicating a passage should be played in a heavily slurred manner
words.name: strascinando or strascicante

words.def: Noisy, forceful
words.name: strepitoso

words.def: Tight, narrow (i.e. faster or hastening ahead); also, a passage in a fugue in which the contrapuntal texture is denser, with close overlapping entries of the subject in different voices; by extension, similar closely imitative passages in other compositions
words.name: stretto

words.def: Gradually getting faster (literally, tightening, narrowing) (i.e. with a pressing forward or acceleration of the tempo, that is, becoming stretto)
words.name: stringendo

words.def: To be played with a smooth slur, a glissando
words.name: strisciando

words.def: Suddenly (e.g. subito pp, which instructs the player to suddenly drop to pianissimo as an effect)
words.name: subito

words.def: Literally, "on", as in sul ponticello (on the bridge); sul tasto (on the fingerboard); sul E (on the E string), etc.
words.name: sul (Ita)

words.def: "on E", indicating a passage is to be played on the E string of a violin. Also seen: sul A, sul D, sul G, sul C, indicating a passage to be played on one of the other strings of a string instrument.
words.name: sul E

words.def: Actual sound. Primarily used with notated harmonics where the written pitch is also the sounding pitch.
words.name: suono reale

words.def: Sul tasto
words.name: sur la touche (Fre)

words.def: A disturbance or interruption of the regular flow of downbeat rhythm with emphasis on the sub-division or up-beat (e.g. in Ragtime music).
words.name: syncopation

words.def: Silent; do not play
words.name: tacet

words.def: On the fingerboard (i.e. in string playing, an indication to bow or to pluck over the fingerboard); playing over the fingerboard produces a duller, less harmonically rich, gentler tone. The opposite of sul ponticello.
words.name: tasto or tastierra (tast.)

words.def: 'single key'; used on a continuo part to indicate that the notes should be played without harmony
words.name: tasto solo

words.def: Time (i.e. the overall speed of a piece of music)
words.name: tempo

words.def: March tempo
words.name: tempo di marcia

words.def: The middle section of a double aria, commonly found in bel canto era Italian operas, especially those of Rossini, Bellini, Donizetti, and their contemporaries as well in many early operas by Verdi. When present, the tempo di mezzo generally signals a shift in the drama from the slow cantabile of the first part to the cabaletta of the second, and this can take the form of some dramatic announcement or action to which the character(s) react in the cabaletta finale.[13]
words.name: tempo di mezzo

words.def: Waltz tempo
words.name: tempo di valse

words.def: In strict time
words.name: tempo giusto

words.def: Resume the original speed
words.name: tempo primo, tempo uno, or tempo I (sometimes tempo I° or tempo 1ero)

words.def: "Robbed time"; an expressive way of performing a rhythm; see rubato
words.name: tempo rubato

words.def: Tenderly
words.name: teneramente; tendre or tendrement (Fre)

words.def: Tenderness
words.name: tenerezza

words.def: The second lowest of the standard four voice ranges (bass, tenor, alto, soprano)
words.name: tenor

words.def: Held (i.e. touch on a note slightly longer than usual, but without generally altering the note's value)
words.name: tenuto

words.def: Having three parts. In particular, referring to a three-part musical form with the parts represented by letters: ABA
words.name: ternary

words.def: The 'best' or most comfortable pitch range, generally used to identify the most prominent / common vocal range within a piece of music
words.name: tessitura

words.def: See Picardy third
words.name: Tierce de Picardie

words.def: The quality of a musical tone that distinguishes voices and instruments
words.name: timbre

words.def: In a jazz or rock score, after a rubato or rallentendo section, the term "time" indicates that performers should return to tempo (this is equivalent to the term "a tempo")
words.name: time

words.def: Rapidly
words.name: tosto

words.def: Calmly, peacefully
words.name: tranquillo

words.def: Three strings (i.e. release the soft pedal of the piano) (see una corda)
words.name: tre corde (tc)
tremolo

words.def: A rapid, usually unmeasured alternation between two harmonically adjacent notes (e.g. a interval of a semitone or a whole tone). A similar alternation using a wider interval is called a tremolo.
words.name: trill

words.def: Three notes in the place of two, used to subdivide a beat.
words.name: triplet (shown with a horizontal bracket and a '3')

words.def: Sad, wistful
words.name: triste

words.def: Broken off, truncated
words.name: tronco, tronca

words.def: Too much; usually seen as non troppo, meaning moderately or, when combined with other terms, not too much, such as allegro [ma] non troppo (fast but not too fast)
words.name: troppo

words.def: Multi-note ornament above and below the main note; it may also be inverted
words.name: turn

words.def: All; all together, usually used in an orchestral or choral score when the orchestra or all of the voices come in at the same time, also seen in Baroque-era music where two instruments share the same copy of music, after one instrument has broken off to play a more advanced form: they both play together again at the point marked tutti. See also ripieno.
words.name: tutti

words.def: One, as for example in the following entries
words.name: un, una, or uno

words.def: A little
words.name: un poco or un peu (Fre)

words.def: One string (i.e. in piano music, depress the soft pedal, altering, and reducing the volume of, the sound). For most notes in modern pianos, this results in the hammer striking two strings rather than three. Its counterpart, tre corde (three strings), is the opposite: the soft pedal is to be released.
words.name: una corda

words.def: In unison (i.e. several players in a group are to play exactly the same notes within their written part, as opposed to splitting simultaneous notes among themselves). Often used to mark the return from divisi.
words.name: unisono (unis) (Fre)

words.def: A fast, lively, or increased tempo or played or done in such a tempo.[14] It is also used as an umbrella term for a quick-paced electronic music style.
words.name: uptempo

words.def: First note of the series ut, re, mi, fa, sol, la, si, in fixed-do solmization.
words.name: ut (Fre)

words.def: The fifth part in a motet, named so most probably because it had no specific range
words.name: vagans (Lat, "wandering"[15])

words.def: A jazz, fusion, and musical theatre term which instructs rhythm section members to repeat and vary a short ostinato passage, riff, or "groove" until the band leader or conductor instructs them to move onto the next section
words.name: vamp till cue

words.def: Variations, con variazioni: with variations/changes
words.name: variazioni

words.def: Velocity, con veloce: with velocity
words.name: veloce

words.def: As quickly as possible; usually applied to a cadenza-like passage or run
words.name: velocissimo

words.def: Away, out, off; as in via sordina or sordina via: 'mute off'
words.name: via

words.def: Vibrating (i.e. a more or less rapidly repeated slight variation in the pitch of a note, used as a means of expression). Often confused with tremolo, which refers either to a similar variation in the volume of a note, or to rapid repetition of a single note.
words.name: vibrato

words.def: Quickly, lively
words.name: vif (Fre)

words.def: cello
words.name: violoncello

words.def: (noun or adjective) performing with exceptional ability, technique, or artistry
words.name: virtuoso

words.def: Fast
words.name: vite (Fre)

words.def: Victoriously
words.name: vittorioso

words.def: Very lively, up-tempo
words.name: vivace

words.def: Very lively
words.name: vivacissimo

words.def: Quickly and lively
words.name: vivamente

words.def: Liveliness, vivacity
words.name: vivezza

words.def: Lively, intense
words.name: vivo

words.def: A music score of an opera, or a vocal or choral composition with orchestra (like oratorio or cantata) where the vocal parts are written out in full but the accompaniment is reduced to two staves and adapted for playing on piano
words.name: vocal score or piano-vocal score

words.def: Voice
words.name: voce

words.def: Flying
words.name: volante

words.def: Turn suddenly (i.e. turn the page quickly). While this indication is sometimes added by printers, it is more commonly indicated by orchestral members in pencil as a reminder to quickly turn to the next page.
words.name: volti subito (V.S.)

words.def: A little, not much
words.name: wenig (Ger)

words.def: Loose, slowly
words.name: wolno (Pol)

words.def: Beat
words.name: Zählzeit (Ger)

words.def: Tender
words.name: zart (Ger)

words.def: Tenderness
words.name: Zartheit (Ger)

words.def: Tenderly
words.name: zärtlich (Ger)

words.def: Sign, mark
words.name: Zeichen (Ger)

words.def: Time-measure (i.e. tempo)
words.name: Zeitmaß or Zeitmass (Ger)

words.def: Zeal, zealous, zealously
words.name: zelo, zeloso, zelosamente

words.def: To draw out
words.name: ziehen (Ger)

words.def: Fairly, quite, rather
words.name: ziemlich (Ger)

words.def: Trembling (i.e. tremolando)
words.name: zitternd (Ger)

words.def: Hesitantly, delaying (i.e. rallentando)
words.name: zögernd (Ger)

words.def: Hold back
words.name: zurückhalten (Ger)
